program_name: MISO Emergency Demand Response (EDR) - Missouri (BEING ELIMINATED)
description: Emergency Demand Response (EDR) was MISO's emergency reliability program that allowed commitment and dispatch of load reductions, behind-the-meter generation, and other demand resources during NERC Energy Emergency Alerts (EEA2, EEA3) or other emergency events. EDR resources received capacity payments through dual registration with LMRs. CRITICAL UPDATE: MISO is eliminating the dual registration of LMRs as EDRs effective Planning Year 2026-2027 (filed with FERC April 25, 2025). The 2025/26 Planning Resource Auction will be the LAST year dual registration is permitted. MISO has NEVER called upon EDRs in its history despite $800 million in capacity payments since 2019.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Same minimum as LMR (100 kW) since EDR was primarily accessed through dual registration with LMRs.

notification_methods: MISO emergency instructions during EEA2/EEA3 events

capacity_rate.notes: EDRs received same capacity payments as LMRs through dual registration. Since nearly 50% of LMRs were cross-registered as EDRs (883 MW registered as EDR in 2023, with only 552 MW also registered as LMR), many resources received capacity payments without genuine performance obligations.

performance_rate.notes: EDR Offer Cap was set to VOLL of $3,500/MWh. MISO proposed to fix EDR Offer Cap at $3,500/MWh even as VOLL increased to $10,000/MWh, effectively decoupling EDR compensation from the VOLL increase. However, this became moot as EDR program is being eliminated.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Minimal penalties for non-performance. Independent Market Monitor expressed concern that EDRs could receive capacity payments with very little incentive to perform since EDRs are never called upon by MISO. This was a primary driver for program elimination.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: Registration required through dual registration with LMR for Planning Resource Auction
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: EDRs were dispatched during emergencies at fixed EDR Offer Cap of $3,500/MWh, not through competitive bidding.

special_attributes: PROGRAM BEING ELIMINATED - Dual registration with LMR ending after Planning Year 2025-2026
MISO has NEVER called upon EDRs in its history
883 MW registered as EDR in 2023, only 552 MW also registered as LMR
Since 2019, DR resources received $800 million in capacity payments with minimal deployment
FERC enforcement actions against Voltus for exploiting dual registration mechanism
Elimination fast-tracked from original 2028-2029 timeline to 2026-2027
FERC requested July 19, 2025 effective date for elimination

program_evolution.change_description: EDR program began receiving significant capacity payments. Total DR resources have received $800 million since 2019.
Peak EDR registration: 883 MW registered as EDR, but only 552 MW cross-registered as LMR, indicating many resources receiving payments without genuine performance obligations
FERC enforcement actions against Voltus for exploiting dual registration mechanism to receive capacity payments without genuine commitment to perform
MISO filed with FERC on April 25, 2025 to eliminate dual registration of LMRs as EDRs effective Planning Year 2026-2027
Planning Year 2025-2026 will be the LAST year dual registration is permitted. EDR program effectively discontinued after this.

data_sources.source_name: MISO Filing - Elimination of Dual Registration for EDR

Substack Analysis - MISO Eliminating Dual Registration

integration_metadata.notes: BATTERY SUITABILITY ASSESSMENT: EDR program is NOT SUITABLE and NO LONGER AVAILABLE for battery energy storage systems. PROGRAM STATUS: DISCONTINUED - The dual registration of LMRs as EDRs is being eliminated effective Planning Year 2026-2027. The 2025-2026 planning year will be the FINAL year this program accepts participants. HISTORICAL CONTEXT: This program's elimination was driven by: (1) MISO has NEVER called upon EDRs in its entire history, (2) $800 million in capacity payments since 2019 with zero actual deployment, (3) FERC enforcement actions for market manipulation, (4) 40% of registered EDRs were not also registered as LMRs, indicating payment without performance obligations. RECOMMENDATION FOR BATTERIES: DO NOT pursue EDR registration. Instead, evaluate: (1) LMR-DR program for capacity market participation (active and suitable), (2) Electric Storage Resource (ESR) model for energy market participation (active and well-suited), (3) DRR Type II for energy market demand response (active but limited suitability). The elimination of EDR removes a potential revenue stream but also eliminates a program that had minimal deployment likelihood and increasing regulatory scrutiny.
